description: From Middle English stiborne, stibourne, stoburn, stoburne, styburne, stiborn. Origin uncertain.
One theory is that the origin may come from *stybor, *stibor, from Old English stybb (“a stump, stub”) + adj. formative -or as in Old English bitor, English bitter.

entries.meaning: Refusing to move or to change one's opinion; obstinate; firmly resisting; persistent in doing something.
examples: He is pretty stubborn about his political beliefs, so why bother arguing?
Blood can make a very stubborn stain on fabrics if not washed properly.

entries.meaning: Of materials: physically stiff and inflexible; not easily melted or worked.
A disease of citrus trees characterized by stunted growth and misshapen fruit, caused by Spiroplasma citri.
